updateData.data: This is cell a on simplePage.
This is cell b on simplePage.

content.text: Basics: Pages and Namespaces

A page is the name of a single "document" in the workspace. It includes the formatted decription text and the cells. However, the page is more than just a display. It is a namespace for the cells on that page. In addition to these cells, it can also have child pages.

To demonstrate what the page is we have added some child pages to this document. We will use this to show how the page relates the the cells and to show the scope rules for accessing cells on different pages.

To add a page, go to the tree panel on the left and select the main page. Open its context menu by right clicking on the page name or by using the page icon which doubles as a menu. Select the option "Add Child Page". Here the create/properties dialog opens where you set the name.
We have added a single page,
simplePage,
as a child to the current page.
Page as a Namespace
Below we illustrate how a page is really a namespace for the cells on it.
We set the value of the cell
simplePageData
below to the page
simplePage
. We see
simplePage

behaves like a javascript object whose content is the cell values on it. This works not only for data cells but also function cells. Of course, if there were function cells on that page they would not show properly on this data cell which only shows JSON values.
We access simplePage simply by using its name, since it is a child to the current page, as we see in the tree panel, even though it does not show on the page itself.
Scope Rules
We see above we can access a page just by using its name. We can access the child of a page just as you would expect.
The rule for access variable names (cells, pages, etc) from a given page is as follows:
If there are local variables with the variable name given, those are used first, according to the standard rules of javascript.
If there are not local variables from the calling function/formula, the local page is checked to see if it has a variable of that name.
If there are no variables on the local page, the parent page is checked. This repeats for each parent page.
If the variable is not found in local code or on any of the pages, lastly global javascript variables are checked.
Using the above rules, there are multiple ways to access a given variable/cell. For example, if we are on page
childPage
, we can access data on that page either by using the cell name, for example
a
, or by using the name of cell A as referenced from a parent page, for example
childPage.a
This page just contains some simple data fields.
